column21:
High attrition rate. Low morale. High stress environment.

Stack ranked bonus structure fosters terrible work environment, with little collaboration and highly subjective ratings. It is common for many folks to work significant overtime, making the bonus negligible relative to the time and effort most employees expend.

Horrible leadership. They do little to shield others from politics and demonstrate no accountability down the ranks, communicate very poorly and do a bad job of supporting and motivating employees. The positive spin put on all messaging is charming at first, but quickly reveals itself to be nothing other than a facade. Leaders seen immune to criticism, uninformed and quick to disseminate undue stress and blame down the ranks on hard working and intelligent employees. Despite a convoluted and overly time consuming review process and stack ranking system, there is no feedback mechanism to comment on folks up the chain. 

Company's size leads little room for advancement or growth.

Focus on efficiency rewards poor quality software. Weak overseas resources leads to hard to maintain software.

Flat environment. You can talk to the managers without much pressure. A growing company, hence there's a lot of potential contribution. Well paid. Young peers so there's not much seniority pressure. 

IF you are someone who thinks constructively and likes the challenges, I think this company can give you a good experience especially at your first job. They're not very restrictive on how you handle your work, and when they are, you'll see that what they do is only to help you improve your practices.
column21:
Weird management system. Since its global, there are on the ground managers and industry managers. It's okay if your on the analyst level and you're talking to them. But I can't imagine how the paradigm work when you work your ladder. I also agree that the career ladder is a bit blury, and I don't think most people would like to work for long in this company. 

If you're not going to take things constructively, you're going to hate this company. hate the competition, hate the management for being competitive and structural, hate the diversity of the people around.

Not much benefits. 

I'm coming from a young generation, and we don't have a large divider on work and life. I've seen colleagues who can swiftly turn to work then to their personal stuff, hence work life balance is not much of an issue. But if you value your time outside work and to not be affected by work, you won't like it here. Although I've had minimum off-time requests from the company, checking emails became my habit in and out of the office.

This is not a place for journalists.

The place is a word factory, and you get articles from a file of stories. Management does not welcome any new ideas or initiatives. 

Very outdated software for filing and takes several minutes to file even smaller stories. 

Many managers are simply incompetent, with little or no knowledge in many cases of what they are supervising and covering. 

Projects are poorly executed with little thought.

Promotions based on whether your are pals with your manager, and absolutely nothing to do with one's ability and achievements. So, somebody who can hardly write and knows hardly anything about a certain subject can find themselves in a higher position. Good reporters that work hard are troublemakers and will find themselves at the bottom of the pile very quickly. 

Company very much has a "don't rock the boat mentality," which ranges from software used for filing to the type of copy filed. 

I've watched while managers would scream at other people and threaten to sack them on the spot,  clearly enjoying their power to do so.

It is assembly-line journalism. The Arlington office is laid back and sort of low energy. Enthusiasm and good ideas are not rewarded at SNL, so everyone is just going through the motions with their heads down. 
You get assigned a story in the system and rewrite it. The more rewrites you do and the faster you do them, the more you get in bonuses (like a dog getting treats for obeying its master). Your industry and journalism experience has little value here because you don't have much opportunity to use it. In fact, if you stray from the assembly-line re-writes and try to do enterprise articles, you run the risk of being charged with an error, which will severely dock your bonus. Everything you do -- number of re-writes, words in them, supposed errors (you can be charged with an error even if it is not one under the establish criteria) are tracked by management. 
There is only middle management in Arlington that reports to senior management elsewhere. No chance of becoming senior management in Arlington, so working there is just a job, not a career. The senior managers that Arlington reports to are not qualified to be senior managers. They were promoted for their adherence to the company philosophy of (PAPOP) procedures are priority over people.

Two things really concerned me about the company's greater strategy/direction: 1) The acquisition of SNL by New Mountain Capital (Private Equity Company) in 2011 2) SNL's increasing reliance on foreign outsourced labor. I felt while I was there no middle managers knew or would tell us what direction they thought New Mountain Capital would take the company. I'd heard NMC had been placing increasing pressure on certain departments, especially account management and sales--no surprise, right? I also experienced and heard about even more trouble with SNL's foreign offices. In some cases some of the foreign employees seemed like they were heavily loaded down and this affected efficiency for US based employees. It also seemed like a number of tasks that were being performed by lower US employees could easily be outsourced...if I were a new employee or low on the pole, I'd be concerned. 

A lot of the middle managers seemed like the only reason they were where they were was because they stuck around. Promotions seemed to have a lot more to do with vacancies than new positions or expansion...Again seemed like there was some vast disconnects between executives and middle managers. Some middle managers did not seem to know/understand what their departments were actually capable of i.e. it seemed there was a a misunderstanding of what they numbers meant or what growth was possible. 

I don't know what an average turnover rate is for a company for SNL is but I want to say they told us it was around 15% when I was there. 

Basically if I was an applicant, I would ask lots and lots of specific questions when or before applying! I'm going to recommend the company in this review but my approval is very much contingent on the department, manager and expectations of the position.

column22: While understandably constrained by financial arrangements aimed at maximizing the enterprise value for the majority owner/investor, New Mountain Capital, I would like to see a loosening of restrictions on granting restricted stock to a wider pool of top-performing employees as a retention tool and to instill a greater sense of vested interest and financial incentive to perform at the highest level. Additionally, the virtual elimination of the 401(k) matching contribution during the global financial crisis and ahead of the company's sale, leaves a bad taste in anyone's mouth who were brought aboard under the impression that there was a traditional matching contribution plan (up to 6% of income) for retirement funding. It's sudden and unfortunate demise only adds fuel to speculation that while he company is adding headcount (largely off-shore) and expanding its offerings, the moves are motivated with an eye toward short-term revenues and margins. If SNL is going to retain its best employees over the course of the next 3-5 years, we will need to genuinely embrace and commit to its pay-for-performance culture, which has suffered as a result of these changes. column21:
Low salaries, that are supposed to be made up with bonuses.

But last year they moved to the infamous system started by GE's Jack Welsh, with each employee rated either a 1,2,3,or 4, with the 1s getting no bonuses and pushed out the door and 4s getting the best bonus. The problem is each rating  period the ratings have to fit a mandated percentage, with 15-20% having to be rated 1s regardless of performance, only 10% 4s, and the rest in between. 

The result is that managers are forced to make up excuses for rating someone  lower than their actual performance, which is not only unethical, but also has resulted in a lot of very good employees either being pushed out the door or leaving on their own because they are so fed up with the whole  process. Employee morale has also plummeted because workers are no longer compensated based on performance but rather on the need to meet mandate quotas, with managers caught in the middle and very frustrated

Upper management doesn't care because they don't see their employees as valuable assets but rather as cogs in a machine that can be replaced at any time, which is not the case for many of the employees because they  do tasks that require a lot of industry specific knowledge and experience. As for those who do other things, their jobs are being shipped to Pakistan and India anyway.

Other HR policies have also becoming increasingly bad over the past few years, from employees not being allowed to carry over ANY unused leave the end of the year to the company basically eliminating any 401K matching contributions. 

Thus, for whatever reason top management has turned very hostile to their employees, and the result is I've never worked in a place where the employees dislike the company they work for so much, even though they might  like their specific jobs. Thus, many are leaving, and those who stay only do so because they cannot find work elsewhere. As soon as the economy turns around, however, they also will be able to find jobs and SNL will realize how much talent they've lost that is very difficult to replace.
column22: Get rid of the Jack Welch philosophy and return to paying your workers based on their true performances, eliminate most of the crushing number of procedures that must be followed and the many managers in charge of developing and implementing them, and recognize your employees as valuable assets rather than readily replaceable cogs in a machine.
